thread.title: Team GB star Max Litchfield faces competition this weekend from his own brother Joe at BUCS Nationals - Mirror Online
thread.title_full: Team GB star Max Litchfield faces competition this weekend from his own brother Joe at BUCS Nationals - Mirror Online

author: Chris Brereton
title: Team GB star Max Litchfield faces competition this weekend from his own brother Joe at BUCS Nationals - Mirror Online
text:
Sport Team GB star Max Litchfield faces competition this weekend from his own brother Joe at BUCS Nationals Rio 2016 star Litchfield and younger brother Joe will battle it out in the pool at the BUCS Nationals event on Sunday Share The Litchfield brothers are both taking swimming by storm Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Team GB swimming star Max Litchfield is in at the deep end this weekend - and will have to fend off his own brother in a bid for glory. 
Pontefract's Litchfield – who starred at Rio 2016 - and younger brother Joe, will battle it out against each other in the 400m and 200m individual medley finals at the BUCS Nationals event at Ponds Forge, Sheffield, on Sunday. 
Max, 21, has already hit the spotlight after shining as part of Team GB at Rio last year, narrowly missing out on a medal after finishing fourth in the men's 400m IM final. 
He admits that facing his younger brother is an entirely different prospect but Max says he has to try and treat the race like any other. 
And he promised that it will be more brotherly love than brotherly shove in Sheffield as he wants to help Joe go all the way. 
He grinned: “There will be a bit of banter flying about beforehand as there usually is because this is the most high-profile competition we've ever raced at together. 
“I just have to be professional when I'm in the pool and he is just another opponent while the race is on – I won't even try and push him in either! Max Litchfield and his brother Joe will go head to head this weekend 
“We are both pretty quiet before we swim and Joe certainly doesn't need any tips from me. Once it's all over, we will get out of the pool and be brothers again.” 
Although Joe is three years younger than Max, he has also made the swimming world sit up and take notice in recent years. 
He became the European junior champion last year as well and also won a silver medal in the Commonwealth Youth Games in Samoa in 2015. 
And although he would love to stun his big brother in Sheffield, he accepts he has two tough races ahead. 
He said: “I hope to be able to catch him in a couple of years and I want to be able to compete and beat him sooner rather than later. 
“We always push each other on and chat about swimming – our coaches discuss technique and stuff like that but Max is always giving me help with preparation and competing. 
“It will be fun to be in the same races and we might even be in the next lane to each other – which would make life interesting!” 
The brothers, sponsored by Australian swimwear company Funky Trunks, may be enemies this weekend but they are united in one goal – they would love to both fly the Team GB flag together. 
Max said: “It would be great to compete at Tokyo with Joe – there is a long way to go before that but he is very talented and has a great future.” 
Funky Trunks is the Australian swimwear brand designed for serious performance without the serious attitude. For more information please visit: www.funkytrunks.com Like us on Facebook
